fields.description:
Nowadays, when Audit Logs are enabled, the records will be saved in the database.

When we need to ask for a customer's Audit Logs, they need to do one of the following:
# Click *Dashboard*.
# Click the *All Plans* tab.
# Click the plan in the list and then choose *Actions > Configure Plan*.
# Click the *Audit Log* tab.
# Copy the results that will be displayed.
# Paste the results in the support ticket.

Or:
# Run the SQL below in their database:
{code:sql}
SELECT * FROM AUDIT_LOG;
{code}
# Copy/export the results that will be displayed.
# Paste/attach the results in the support ticket.

It would be much easier if the Audit Logs were outputted in a log file. The customer would only need to attach them to the support ticket.
fields.summary: Output Audit Logs in a log files a continuous deployer, I want plans to not run if not triggered by the branch/tag they are associated with

fields.description:
h3. Problem
* Mac OS X requires binaries to be signed with a Developer ID certificate to run out of the box on mac os x. Without code signing, you should get a warning that the app isn't from the App Store or a registered Apple Developer.
* This used not to be a problem as users were told how to fix it
* Latest versions of Mac OS X report that the download is corrupted rather than blocked by developer id. This is an apple bug. Getting to them to fix it will be near impossible.

!upload.png!

h3. Possible solution
* We get a Developer ID certificate and sign our installer binary with it. This is easy to get - we have one for HipChat and we can generate another one.
* Make code signing work
*# We use the command line tool to resign each binary after install4j has packaged it (mac only). This would require us to package it manually as a DMG *not preferred*
*# Upgrade to the latest install4j 5.x and use its [built in code signing|http://resources.ej-technologies.com/install4j/help/doc/indexRedirect.html?http&&&resources.ej-technologies.com/install4j/help/doc/helptopics/concepts/codeSigning.html] to sign the developer id certificate. This should work on all platforms and be automated *preferred*
fields.summary: Installer package is "damaged and cannot be reopened" on Mac OS X

fields.description:
Consider a user repository where we have following users:
* Piotr Stefaniak;pstefaniak@atlassian.com
* Przemek Bruski;pbruski@atlassian.com
* Lech Wałęsa;leszek@wp.pl
* Stefan Batory;piecia@o2.pl

In the user picker (for example notification/permission/responsibilities) I can write up "Piotr" "Przemek" "Lech" and the corresponding user appear - cool. However if I don't remember the first name, but I remember the last name (for example I start writing Stefaniak instead of Piotr) - I won't hit any results.

Question is, can we somehow improve the user searcher to search for every separate string found in his Name field?

In the example above, if I would input "Stefan" into the user picker I'd expect the picker to hint me to two entries: Piotr *Stefan*_iak and *Stefan* Batory.

Is that possible?
fields.summary: Improve user searcher to allow searching by last name

fields.description:
Bamboo has the AgentOfflineEvent per the JavaDoc : http://docs.atlassian.com/atlassian-bamboo/4.1/com/atlassian/bamboo/v2/build/events/AgentOfflineEvent.html

Can you provide in a future release additional Events that would signifcantly improve plugins/custom code for handling numerous remote agents :

An AgentOnlineEvent for throwing an event when an existing Agent comes back online after being offline.

An AgentRegistrationRequestEvent thrown when a new agent attempts to get authorized to bamboo (assuming remote agent authorization is enabled).

An AgentAuthorizedEvent when an admin approves an agent pending approval in the Agent Auth tab.

An AgentEnabledEvent when an admin manually enables a disabled agent (not just a AgentConfigurationUpdatedEvent event).

An explicit AgentDisabledEvent when an admin manually disables an enabled agent (not just AgentConfigurationUpdatedEvent)

An AgentDeletedEvent thrown when an admin manually deletes an Agent in admin panel.

An AgentRequestStopEvent when an admin manually clicks to request an agent stop. I'm not sure yet if this action triggers an AgentOfflineEvent directly, though it may eventually, but might be good to separate out to the cases. A manul stop is different scenario than an unknown or unexpected failure in which case I would expect AgentOfflineEvent.
fields.summary: Provide Additional Agent Event Listeners in addition to AgentOfflineEvent

fields.description:
In looking into triggering Bamboo Plans remotely, I don't see a documented way to override Plan variables either when triggering the Plan via GET /api/rest/updateAndBuild.action?buildKey=PROJECT-PLAN , or adding it to the queue via POST /rest/api/latest/queue/PROJECT-PLAN .

Is there such a way, perhaps by POSTing a bit of json or XML?
fields.summary: Unable to override variables when remotely triggering a plan

fields.description:
The notification emails that Bamboo sends out are missing the Plan_Name when notifying about a Plan's Branch.

In the notification emails that Bamboo sends out, the subject and initial (HTML) header line read:

--
Subject: [Bamboo] Project_Name > Plan_Name > #Build has failed

Project_Name > Plan_Name > #Build failed
--

When a Branch has been configured on a plan, the email regarding the Branch reads:

--
Subject: [Bamboo] Project_Name > Branch_Name > #Build has failed

Project_Name > Branch_Name > #Build failed
--

With a number of our Plans having the same Branch identifier, the lack of the Plan_Name makes these mails less than helpful.  I'm expecting to see something like:

--
Subject: [Bamboo] Project_Name > Plan_Name (Branch_Name) > #Build has failed

Project_Name > Plan_Name (Branch_Name) > #Build failed
--

This would help in more quickly determining which developer(s) should be the recipient of my nerf-laden anger :)
fields.summary: Notification emails for branches do not include the plan name

fields.description:
Currently, if the source of the git project has the autocrlf = true parameter, this will not be reflected after it was check out by Bamboo. Steps to replicate the problem:
# Create a git repository The configuration is shown as follow:
+Global configuration+
.gitconfig
{code}
[user]
	name = admin
	email = admin@yahoo.com
{code}
+Git repository configuration+
.git/config
{code}
[core]
	repositoryformatversion = 0
	filemode = false
	bare = false
	logallrefupdates = true
	symlinks = false
	ignorecase = true
	hideDotFiles = dotGitOnly
	autocrlf = true
{code}
# Add items to the newly created git repository and commit it
# Create a new plan in Bamboo and configure the repository point to the newly created git repository
# Make sure the job run the repository check out task
# Now check .git/config file via _<Bamboo home>\xml-data\build-dir\<project>-<plan>-<jobname>_
# Open the .git/config and you might find that the following autocrlf = false:
{code}
[core]
	repositoryformatversion = 0
	filemode = false
	logallrefupdates = true
	autocrlf = false
{code} 


However, the problem does not exist if the source is checkout using the script task with the following command:
{code}
git clone file:///C:/git/
{code}

The following is the result of the .git/config via _<Bamboo home>\xml-data\build-dir\<project>-<plan>-<jobname>:
{code}
[core]
	repositoryformatversion = 0
	filemode = false
	bare = false
	logallrefupdates = true
	symlinks = false
	ignorecase = true
	hideDotFiles = dotGitOnly
[remote "origin"]
	fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
	url = file:///C:/git/
[branch "master"]
	remote = origin
	merge = refs/heads/master
{code}

As above the parameter autocrlf is not presented.
fields.summary: Bamboo Git repository checkout will always set autocrlf parameter to be false

fields.description:
Had a couple of people raise issues with bamboo 4.1 and my plugin, turns out in this release there is an inconsistency with the sl4j versions.

{noformat}
atlas-mvn dependency:tree | grep slf4j
[INFO] |  |  |  +- org.slf4j:jcl-over-slf4j:jar:1.6.4:provided
[INFO] |  |  +- org.slf4j:slf4j-api:jar:1.6.4:provided
[INFO] |  |  +- org.slf4j:slf4j-log4j12:jar:1.5.8:test
{noformat}

Note the different for the slf4j-log4j12 in the test scope, at the moment this stops me running any tests for components that log using this library.

All tests pass fine when using bamboo.version of 4.0 in my plugin project.
fields.summary: Library version clash for sl4j which lead to errors using certain log methods

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.1, I have several remote agents configured and running builds. In my browser I explicitly logout using the logout link, close browser, and start fresh browser session and try using several direct links to Bamboo plans and get prompted to login, which is expected behavior. I do not login, but if I visit URL http://<my-bamboo-host-and-port>/agent/viewAgents.action I can view the list of all agents, click an agent name, and drill down to view the agents details.

Note, the link to the Local Agent works and allows an anonymous user to view Local Agent details including a list of all of its recent builds and the capabilities configured on it (security information leakage).

The links to the remote agent prompt for login as the links are : 

/admin/agent/viewAgent.action?agentId=131076

BUT if I change the link to :

/agent/viewAgent.action?agentId=131076

I can then view the list of builds for that agent and its capabilities. This is a medium-severity security issues as information leakage.
fields.summary: Anonymous users can view remote agent details

fields.description:

Alternatively, upgrade to Bamboo 4.2 for a fix.
fields.summary: Corrupted Applink causes Bamboo Import to fail

fields.description:
Not sure if this is a bug or improvements....

I have a scheduled plan in Bamboo set to build every second (using the Cron Expression). Seems to work fine. I marked the Plan Disabled from the Actions dropdown menu. I have Bamboo running via console.bat file on Windows so I can watch console standard out messages scroll by. Even though the plan is disabled I still see the messages "Running Quartz Strategy Job for MYPROJECT-MYBUILD fly by every single second (since i have my plan scheduled to run every second).

I would think if a plan is disabled that somehow you could disable the Quartz job too so it isn't polling. This could be a little bit of a performance hit in larger installations with hundreds of plans.
fields.summary: When Plans Are Disabled The Background Quartz Job Keeps Polling

fields.description:
h2. Problem
Presently Bamboo allows cleaning of directory *after* each succesfull build. It will be a great idea to clean *before* builds as well. This has the added advantage of providing the following:

{noformat}
* debugging - as generated files could be easily inspected without resorting to artifacts
* ensuring behaviour for aborted builds
* takes care of possible nasty linking interference cases when a new build produces less files or a different set of objects than the previous one
* generally when certain tools get confused about already existing files (or folders with the same name, etc.)
{noformat}

h2. Solution
Use "Clean working directory task" to clean working directory in a Job. If this task is a first task in a Job it will be run *before* artifact dependencies are downloaded.
fields.summary: Clean working directory before each successful build

fields.description:
Recently we found our Bamboo server disk space hitting particular free space thresholds. We configured stricter artifact retention policies for some of our more artifact-heavy plans, and increased base restrictions for the global expiry.
While we can see the build expiry process running, it seems to taking more than a week to get through a full build expiry run, even though we've set Bamboo to run build expiry every night.
The expiry process needs to be more performant. It seems to be a serial process, so multi-threading it would be a start.
Additionally, instead of an expiry process kicking off at the global expiry time, it might be a possibility to have each build run the plan expiry process at the end of the build.
fields.summary: Improve performance of build expiry process

fields.description:
I have a Bitbucket service hook for Bamboo.

No matter which branch is committed to, the service hook is fired. Bamboo dutifully builds "master" even if the branch in the commit was something else.

If the commit data associated with the trigger does not contain the branch/tag associated with the plan, the plan should not run.

I've also asked Bitbucket to provide a branch/tag scope on service hooks to further improve things from that end.
fields.summary: As a continuous deployer, I want plans to not run if not triggered by the branch/tag they are associated with

fields.description:
Users will want to be able to transition JIRA issues based on the completion of bamboo builds. A common use case will be the opportunity to reopen issues whenever the build fails or resolve the issue whenever the build is a success. We have implemented this feature already in JIRA studio and Ondemand version as described in the page below:

* https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRASTUDIO/Integrating+Builds+with+your+Issues+Workflow

This is not achievable on standalone JIRA because the bamboo specific workflow properties are not recognised.
fields.summary: Introduce the builds workflow in JIRA standalone

fields.description:
When there are a lot of Projects and Plans configured in your Bamboo instance, navigating around can result in a lot of waits for the list of all plans to render.

In the per-Project page (the one listing the Plans in that Project), it'd be Really Nifty to be able to go to the previous or next Project in an alphabetical sort, rather than going to the list of all plans.  Likewise for the previous or next Plan within a Project.

( I find that I need to navigate through a lot of plans on a random basis, and favouriting the plans doesn't especially help )
fields.summary: Links to Previous and Next Projects/Plans

fields.description: I'm using this REST API command: http://localhost:8085/rest/api/latest/result/MPR-MPL-17?expand=artifacts&expand=jiraIssues&favourite=false&start-index=0&max-results=3 Project Key: MPR Plan Key: MPL Build Number: 17 This build produced artifacts. They are located at {{BAMBOO_HOME\artifacts\MPR-MPL\JOB1\build-00017\My-Artifact-Definition}}, and can be seen at http://localhost:8085/browse/MPR-MPL-17/artifact/JOB1/My-Artifact-Definition as well. The REST command results in this XML: {code:xml} My Plan My Project 2012-05-29T18:19:02.760-03:00 Tue, 29 Mai, 06:19 PM 2012-05-29T18:19:07.968-03:00 Tue, 29 Mai, 06:19 PM 5 5208 5 seconds 1 week ago 193 No tests found 0 0 0 Manual build by Admin {code} As can be seen, no artifacts were identified, so the {{artifacts}} element was not expanded.
fields.summary: REST API does not expand artifacts

fields.description: At the moment users with the bamboo-admin global permission can can edit the [global permission|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO040/Granting+global+permissions+to+users+or+groups] and even revoke themselves the right to admin Bamboo. This should not be allowed as doing so will mean that no one has access to administration menu in Bamboo.
fields.summary: Bamboo should not allow admin users to remove themselves from the admin global permissions
Support custom fields for JIRA issue creation
Automatically select the project in the issue creation that is linked to the current project

fields.description: It would be cool (and very useful) if for each agent you could specify an email address to notify if it goes offline. For example as "owner" of the Bamboo server I want to be notified if any agent(s) go offline, but I have up to 100 agents some run by different software teams hosted on virtual machines I don't have access to. Administratively it would be great if when authorizing an agent to run in the admin panel i can set an email address specific to that agent of someone to get notified in addition to the bamboo admin person/team.
fields.summary: Allow Each Bamboo Remote Agent to have an email notification field if they go offline
Bamboo does not support SCP-like urls in Git

fields.description:
On the plugin management page, if I click the pause button, followed quickly by the cancel pause button, Bamboo will pause then unpause as expected.

However if a build is running at the time, then it will pause itself again later once that build finishes. I'm not sure if a build just has to be running, or requests for builds have to be coming in as well for this to occur.

Attached a screenshot of it going from "RUNNING" to "PAUSED" without going to "PAUSING" first.

I think this happens because the queue watcher doesn't get cancelled properly when resumeServer() is called. The queue watcher spins in a loop waiting to transition the server from "PAUSING" to "PAUSED". When you call resumeServer(), it sends a cancel to the watcher.

I'm unsure, but I believe that since the watcher has a second callable inside it that blocks when build requests are being made, the watcher is cancelled but the inner blocked callable hangs around and executes anyway, transitioning it from "RUNNING" directly to "PAUSED".
fields.summary: Pausing and quickly unpausing bamboo while builds are running causes it to pause again some time later

fields.description:
Currently the button is at the Plugin Manager page.

If there are builds running and editing the disk data, it is very likely that import/export processes will fail.

Maybe the import/export buttons should be enabled only after the "Pause Server" one was clicked?

fields.description:
Currently, docs are served out of the BAMBOO40 space. This was a work-around for problems associated with the 4.0 release.

Those issues have been investigated and resolved.
We now want a new BAMBOO space, and have the docs served from there.
(/) Delete existing BAMBOO space on CAC
(/) Copy BAMBOO40 to a new BAMBOO
(x) Need an ADM ticket to change the current redirect for context-sensitive help:

In /files/host/atlassian04.managed.contegix.com/var/www/domains/atlassian.com/docs/htdocs/atlassian-bamboo:

RewriteRule ^/?docs-041/(.*)$ https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO40/$1  [L]
should be:
RewriteRule ^/?docs-041/(.*)$ https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/$1  [L]

fields.description:
Jira Issues Page Breaks in a Linked Jira Issue Gets Deleted in Jira Or Links to a Non-Existent Issue

In Bamboo 4.1, If i link several Jira issues to a build they can be viewed on the Jira Issues tab see attachment. I have linked issues from Jira with keys JTP-1 JTP-2 and JTP-3

If I click the Add Linked Issue button and type in the issue key JTP-4 (this issue does not exist in Jira) then it adds it to the list just fine and then all the listed Jira issues break and no details display. I would expect that only the line for the invalid Jira issue would not display or show problems displaying the info, not all the lines.

Normally you would know if you type an issue key and click save and it corrupts the list. However I also tested out creating the issue JTP-4 in Jira. The previously nonworking Issues tab in Bamboo worked now once I refreshed the page since the JTP-4 issue now actually exists in Jira. However, imagine over months or years, issues in Jira may accidentally or intentionally get deleted. I deleted jira issue JTP-4 and went back to Bamboo page and the Issues tab was broken again not displaying any of the data. This is the more negative use case since Bamboo build teams may not ever know which issue was deleted in Jira that caused the page to stop displaying the issue information correctly.
fields.summary: Jira Issues Page Breaks if a Linked Jira Issue Gets Deleted in Jira Or Links to a Non-Existent Issue

fields.description: In a plan config, when you enable the 'override global build expiry' you can specify a time frame or number of builds to keep. If will be very useful if you could specify a number if SUCCESSFUL builds to keep and/or a number if FAILED builds to keep, and most importantly a checkbox that says "always keep SUCCESSFUL builds" that overrides any expiry and ensures all successful builds remain and only failed builds get expired, if applicable.
fields.summary: Specify Failed Vs Successful Builds to Keep in Build Expiry

fields.summary: View related branches

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.1 - I have a build plan where I have build expiry overridden but have specified labels to keep such as "keep". As UserA with full plan admin permissions I assign a Label to a successful build result "keep". This means I want that build to NEVER be expired as it is a critical build.

If I log in as UserB, who has ONLY View permissions on the build, I can go to the successful build, and REMOVE all the labels on that build. Then if the nightly build expiry runs my successful build I THOUGHT I marked to not be deleted can get deleted.

EVEN WORSE, if the Plan is set to have View Permissions to all logged in user, then any logged in user can remove the build result label thus causing the build to be cleaned up and lost due to expiry.

I'm not sure if i consider this a bug or a security flaw (possibly both).
fields.summary: Bamboo - User With View Permissions Can Remove a Build Result Label Thereby Negatively Affecting Build Expiry

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.1, a user can add comments to a build result without having any edit permissions.

If a User ONLY has View permissions on the plan they seem to be able to add comments.

I would not think a user with only VIEW permissions should be able to alter ANYTHING on the build, including adding comments.
fields.summary: Build comments permissions

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.1, a user can Add/Modify Plan Label. For example while logged in as a user (UserA) with full permissions to a plan (View, Edit, Admin, etc). I add a Plan Label.

UserB ONLY has View permissions on the plan. If I log in as UserB I can remove the label and add others.

I would not think a user with only VIEW permissions should be able to alter ANYTHING on the build, including labels.
fields.summary: Bamboo - Modify Plan Label Permissions

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.1, the 'Assign Responsible User' for a build result that is broken needs a permissions setting. For example while logged in as a user (UserA) with full permissions to a plan (View, Edit, Admin, etc). I assign responsibility to UserB .

UserB ONLY has View permissions on the plan. If I log in as UserB I can remove the assignment of responsibility from the build and assign another user.

I would not think a user with only VIEW permissions should be able to alter ANYTHING on the build, including build responsibility.
fields.summary: Bamboo 'Assign Responsible User' Needs Permissions

fields.description: In Bamboo 4.1, Jira Issues can be manually created from the build summary. It would be fantastic if you could specify in the Plan Config that if a build fails to automatically create a Jira issue using a specified type, priority, assignment, etc.
fields.summary: Automatically Create Jira Issue

fields.description:
In Bamboo 4.1 release, for a build result you can Create a Jira Issue. Similarly, it would be great, especially if your build failed, if from the build result page you could create a FECRU Code Review, see it listed on the build result page.

Additionally if you create the review it would be useful to say that review should continue to be linked to all new bamboo builds until the review is closed and/or until the bamboo build changes status. Scenario might be you break a bamboo build, then you create a code review tied to that broken build and say all builds thereafter stay linked to that code review until the build passes and/or you close the build.
fields.summary: Create Code Review in Bamboo for Fisheye/Crucible Directly From Bamboo Build Results

fields.description:
We have the issue that Bamboo 4.0 build 2906 sometimes fails Maven build tasks in the middle of their execution, and then complains that it could not find a "build success" message in the last 250 log entries.

It does not seem to occur if we stick to just one local agent. With multiple local agents and multiple build running at the same time, however, this problem occurs quite often (every 20-30th build roughly). 

Here's a sample log excerpt, as you can see that Bamboo is failing the task even though the Maven build process obviously has not finished yet. 

...
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   T E S T S
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   -------------------------------------------------------
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   There are no tests to run.
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   Results :
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   Tests run: 0, Failures: 0, Errors: 0, Skipped: 0
build   14-May-2012 17:06:05   
simple  14-May-2012 17:06:05   Failing task since text 'BUILD SUCCESS' was not found in last 250 log entries
simple  14-May-2012 17:06:05   Finished task 'Maven 2.x'
...
fields.summary: Bamboo fails Maven task while the build is still running, when using multiple local agents

fields.description:
Previous versions of Bamboo (3.4?) opened the "Create Job" in a dialog box (I recall Nathan was implementing that). Current version opens it as a new page, which looks ugly. No functionality is lost, however UX suffers a bit.

Steps to reproduce:
1) Create new plan.
2) Go to it's configuration->stages
3) Under the "default stage" there is "default job" and "+ create job". Click the latter.
4a) A new page appears where you can create new job or clone job.
4b) Where I expected a new popup will appear (with the same contents) - for example like when you hit "Create Stage" on the same page.
fields.summary: Stages->Create Job should popup in a dialog instead of new page

Would be cool to link to some CAC document (or even Jira documentation) that shows what is and how to turn on 'issue linking'

fields.description:
Create a user and give them access to use restricted admin in Bamboo. As that user go directly to the path:

/builds/build/admin/configureGlobalPermissions.action

If you refresh the page or go to the view page, you won't have any permissions to do that because they will have been erased.
Effect: Data loss (in the form of who can do what), DoS (people can't use Bamboo), support costs (fixing it will be a PITA for our supporters).

This was first picked up in OnDemand, but I think it is a bamboo + webwork problem. Tim Moore was able to reproduce this on a bamboo 4 standalone instance.
fields.summary: Going directly to Bamboo's configureGlobalPermissions.action erases all permissions
